awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track A: A Multi-dimensional Approach to Transform Tribal Community Resilience Against Extreme Wind Hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Civic Innovation Challenge Planning Grant (CIVIC-PG) is to support research on mitigating extreme wind hazards in Midwest tribal communities by co-developing, co-implementing, and validating a scalable socio-technical framework and a web-based computational platform to predict and assess risk and resilience. Resilience building within tribal communities has historically met many challenges, including limited technology access, integration, and implementation, lack of skillful workforce, and restricted access to tribal lands. Recent devastating events underscore an urgent need to enhance preparedness and infrastructure planning, particularly for tribes without federal recognition. Among them, extreme wind hazards in the Midwest are most threatening, causing service disruptions, economic instability, and potential loss of life. The computational platform is designed to facilitate information exchange, update preparedness frameworks, map hazard areas, and provide real-time evacuation and resource allocation. Training of local representatives improves data utilization and coverage, thus strengthening community resilience against natural hazards.

The project employs a multi-dimensional approach to 1) discover community vulnerabilities and interactions between technology, environment, infrastructures, and people, (2) create integrated analytical methods and resilience models for tribal communities, and (3) co-develop a web-based computational platform integrating resilience modeling, geographic information system, deep learning, and remote sensing. It brings together diverse expertise and partnerships to transform research and technology into practical solutions to enhancing resilience, promoting technology use, and supporting tribal self-reliance and decision-making. The project contributes to the advancement in interdisciplinary collaboration across resilience modeling, data analysis, geospatial science, and emergency management. The technology and framework are scalable for wider adoption.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program’s Track A. Climate and Environmental Instability - Building Resilient Communities through Co-Design, Adaption, and Mitigation and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Focusing on mitigating the adverse impact from the extreme wind hazards in the Midwest region of the United States, a multi-dimensional approach, including i) societal, ii) infrastructural, iii) environmental, and iv) technological dimensions, was proposed to transform community resilience against extreme wind-related natural disasters. This project aims to transform research and technology into practical tools for community resilience, promoting technology use and training to support community self-reliance and decision-making. The system facilitates information exchange, updates preparedness frameworks, maps hazard areas, and provides real-time evacuation and resource allocation. Training local representatives will improve data utilization and preparedness, thus strengthening community resilience against natural hazards. Through this Stage 1 project, the research team completed a series of proposed activities to prepare for the full development and implementation of the envisioned deliverables of the Stage 2 project.

Intellectual Merit

This project proposes a multi-dimensional community-based approach to transform community resilience against significant but understudied natural hazards – extreme wind events in the Midwest. The project will advance interdisciplinary scientific research and application across resilience modeling, multimodal data analysis, geospatial science, and community emergency management. Specifically, the research team completed critical data collection through multiple field visits, workshops, and a research seminar collaborating with the community partners. A high-resolution geospatial database was developed using unmanned aircraft system (UAS) based remote sensing and Geographic Information System (GIS) to organize and communicate data, facilitating community input to advance comprehensive system development. GIS maps these terrain and construction attributes, with its layering and location-based communication features, to enhance community collaboration in identifying vulnerabilities and data needs. Through workshops, conferences, and field visits, the community highlighted challenges related to derechos, tornadoes, wildfire-driven winds, and straight-line winds, with the latter identified as the top priority. Using field visits and open sources such as the National Structure Inventory (NSI), we compiled initial built environment inventories, characterized their interdependencies, and evaluated social frameworks at a low resolution. A housing inventory dataset was developed, detailing roof types, wall types, shingle types, building geometry, and other attributes for Stage 2 modeling. This dataset will support risk assessments of individual buildings or building groups based on wind hazard direction. In addition, historical extreme wind events and the associated meteorological conditions were collected from nearby weather observation stations and the National Weather Service (NWS). Our preliminary experiments labeled 10,000 samples for initial trials to identify the meteorological precursors that may lead to wind damage. Our current research progress and outcomes set a solid foundation for ongoing efforts to transform the community resilience against extreme wind hazards by integrating multidisciplinary approaches.

Broader Impacts

This project aims to deliver innovative, implementable technology and a co-designed framework that benefits our partner community while producing a scalable, transferable model. The research team undertook a number of planning activities and preliminary research and development work to 1) solidify the roles, responsibilities, and management mechanism across the research team and community partners, 2) strengthen collaboration with implementing community partners and expand supporting partners for project advisory, sustainability development, analytical infrastructure support, and project external evaluation that are critical Stage 2 project, and 3) refine the vision and execution plan for comprehensive technology research and development, and implementation in Stage 2. During the planning phase, we facilitated and hosted one collaborative design seminar and three co-design workshops with participation from the primary community partners – Omaha Tribe of Nebraska and Thurston County of Nebraska, including community residents, community leaders, and agencies. Workshop activities included focus group discussions, brainstorming, and design exercises. These workshops led to a greater understanding of the opportunities and challenges these groups have experienced in emergency management, generated new ideas, prioritized data use cases and software features, and created a space for empathy and collaboration across disparate stakeholders. In addition, an advisory board was assembled for professional project consultation, research evaluation, and sustainable development in Stage 2, consisting of representatives from the Nebraska Douglas County Emergency Management Agency, the National Weather Service at Omaha/Valley of Nebraska, and the Nebraska Douglas County GIS Department. The planning grant allowed the proposing team and implementing partners from key user groups to set the foundation for a 12-month stage 2 pilot with the goal of delivering sustainable, scalable, and transferable technology and generating knowledge and best practices to serve as a model for efforts in similar communities.


Last Modified: 04/08/2025
Modified by: Chenyu Huang
